questions.question_text: A placement group in Amazon EC2 can

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
A placement group in Amazon EC2 is used to reduce network latency and increase network throughput between instances. By launching instances within a placement group, you can ensure that they are physically located close to each other in the same Availability Zone. This proximity helps to minimize the network latency between instances, making it beneficial for applications that require low-latency and high-bandwidth communication.

Selected Answer: D
i would go with D - placement group of type Cluster can do this – packs instances close together inside an Availability Zone. This strategy enables workloads to achieve the low-latency network performance necessary for tightly-coupled node-to-node communication that is typical of HPC applications.

choices.A: place high memory instances in one logical group.
choices.D: reduce network latency and increase network throughput
choices.C: isolate any instance-type physically so that groups access local resources.
choices.B: logically name and tag different tiers of the system (DB, application, business logic etc).

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Giving that I don't understand what's and "autoscaling setup" , launch configuration seems optional (https://docs.aws.amazon.com/autoscaling/ec2/userguide/as-process-shutdown.html)

Answer A.

You can take advantage of the safety and reliability of geographic redundancy by spanning your Auto Scaling group across multiple Availability Zones within a region and then attaching a load bal-ancer to distribute incoming traffic across those Availability Zones. Incoming traffic is distributed equally across all Availability Zones enabled for your load balancer.
Reference:
http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AutoScaling/latest/DeveloperGuide/GettingStartedTutorial.html

comments.content: Sorry, this explanation was for question 452

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements is true about Auto Scaling?
questions.answer_description:
You can create an Auto Scaling group to maintain the healthy number of instances at all times, and optionally delete this basic Auto Scaling infrastructure. You can either delete your Auto Scaling set up or delete just your Auto Scaling group and keep your launch configuration to use at a later time.
Reference:
http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AutoScaling/latest/DeveloperGuide/GettingStartedTutorial.html

choices.A: You can only delete your Auto Scaling group but not your Auto Scaling setup.
choices.B: If the Auto Scaling infrastructure is being deleted, it is not mandatory to delete the launch con-figuration.
choices.D: If the Auto Scaling infrastructure is being deleted, it is mandatory to delete the launch configura-tion.
choices.C: You can only delete your Auto Scaling set up but not your Auto Scaling group.

questions.question_text: If you specify only the general endpoint (autoscaling.amazonaws.com), Auto Scaling directs your request to the:

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
If you specify only the general endpoint (autoscaling.amazonaws.com) without specifying a specific region, Auto Scaling directs your request to the default endpoint, which is the us-east-1 (US East - N. Virginia) endpoint. This is the default region for many AWS services, including Auto Scaling, when a specific region is not specified in the endpoint URL.

Correct Answer: D 
 us-east-1 is default for API Calls
If you specify the general endpoint (autoscaling.amazonaws.com), Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling directs your request to the us-east-1 endpoint.
Ans D: When you use an endpoint with no Region, AWS routes the Amazon EC2 request to US East (N. Virginia) (us-east-1), which is the default Region for API calls.

questions.answer_description:
If you just specify the general endpoint (autoscaling.amazonaws.com), Auto Scaling directs your request to the us-east-1 endpoint.
Reference:
http://docs.aws.amazon.com/general/latest/gr/rande.html

questions.question_text:
An organization's security policy requires multiple copies of all critical data to be replicated across at least a primary and backup data center. The organization has decided to store some critical data on Amazon S3.
Which option should you implement to ensure this requirement is met?
questions.answer_description:
You specify a region when you create your Amazon S3 bucket. Within that region, your objects are redundantly stored on multiple devices across multiple facilities. Please refer to Regional Products and Services for details of Amazon S3 service availability by region.
Reference:
https://aws.amazon.com/s3/faqs/

discussion.content: Purposefully given the word : "multiple facilities"...Meaning Availability Zone.

D is the answer

S3 automatically spam copies of your files through 3 AZ's
Yes S3 also has 11 9's of availability

comments.content: The 11 9’s is for Durability!! The Availability depends of type of S3 subscribed... ;)

S3 Standard
Durability: 99.999999999%
Availability: 99.99%
AZs >= 3

S3 Standard-IA
Durability: 99.999999999%
Availability: 99.9%
AZs >= 3

S3 Intelligent-Tiering
Durability: 99.999999999%
Availability: 99.9%
AZs >= 3

S3 One Zone-IA
Durability: 99.999999999%
Availability: 99.5%
AZs = 1

S3 Glacier
Durability: 99.999999999%
Availability: 99.99% (after you restore objects)
AZs >= 3

S3 Glacier Deep Archive
Durability: 99.999999999%
Availability: 99.99% (after you restore objects)
AZs >= 3

RRS (Not recommended)
Durability: 99.99%
Availability: 99.99%
AZs >= 3

discussion.content: D. You do not need to implement anything since S3 data is automatically replicated between multiple facilities

choices.B: You do not need to implement anything since S3 data is automatically replicated between regions
choices.D: You do not need to implement anything since S3 data is automatically replicated between multiple facilities within an AWS Region
choices.A: Use the S3 copy API to replicate data between two S3 buckets in different regions
choices.C: Use the S3 copy API to replicate data between two S3 buckets in different facilities within an AWS Region

questions.question_text: A user has configured ELB with Auto Scaling. The user temporarily suspended the Auto Scaling terminate process. What might the Availability Zone Rebalancing process (AZRebalance) conse-quently cause during this period?
questions.answer_description:
Auto Scaling performs various processes, such as Launch, Terminate, and Availability Zone Re-balance (AZRebalance). The AZRebalance process type seeks to maintain a balanced number of in-stances across Availability Zones within a region. If the user suspends the Terminate process, the AZRebalance process can cause the Auto Scaling group to grow up to ten percent larger than the maximum size. This is because Auto Scaling allows groups to temporarily grow larger than the max-imum size during rebalancing activities. If Auto Scaling cannot terminate instances, the Auto Scal-ing group could remain up to ten percent larger than the maximum size until the user resumes the Terminate process type.
Reference:
http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AutoScaling/latest/DeveloperGuide/US_SuspendResume.html

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
When an Auto Scaling group is configured with ELB (Elastic Load Balancer) and the Auto Scaling terminate process is temporarily suspended, the Availability Zone Rebalancing process (AZRebalance) can still occur. AZ Rebalancing is a feature of Auto Scaling that helps distribute instances evenly across Availability Zones.

During this period, if AZ Rebalancing is triggered, it may move instances between Availability Zones to balance the capacity and maintain an even distribution. As a result, the number of instances in a specific Availability Zone may remain higher than the defined maximum size for that zone.

choices.B: AZ Rebalancing might now allow Auto Scaling to launch or terminate any instances.
choices.A: Auto Scaling will keep launching instances in all AZs until the maximum instance number is reached.
choices.D: It is not possible to suspend the terminate process while keeping the launch active.
choices.C: AZ Rebalancing might allow the number instances in an Availability Zone to remain higher than the maximum size
